title.narrative: Conseils subventionnaires de la recherche en Afrique subsaharienne - étude et atelier régionaux
Science Granting Councils in Sub-Saharan Africa: Regional Study and Workshop

description.narrative:
This project will help IDRC and other stakeholders build relationships and understand the priorities and practices of science granting councils. This will guide future partnerships and investments to advance scientific research in sub-Saharan Africa. The project is part of a global IDRC initiative on science granting councils, which aims to understand them in low- and middle-income countries and to promote collaborative links among them. The objective is to enhance their ability to support development outcomes.
The rationale behind this project is the current trend in African countries to increase their gross expenditures on research and development to at least 1% of gross domestic product (GDP), and to put national policies in place by 2015 to support this effort. New organizations are emerging across the continent to manage research funds, formulate policies, set priorities, build capacity, and provide advisory services on science, technology, and innovation issues. Among these are science granting councils, academies, boards, commissions, foundations, and funds. Their structure, approach, and functions vary from country to country.
This emerging trend calls for a better understanding of Africa's science granting councils' strategic priorities, objectives, and practices. It is equally important to understand the challenges the councils face, the way they seek and develop partnerships, and the best mechanisms for collaboration as a way of enhancing their contribution to national and regional development priorities.
This project will support the Centre for Research on Evaluation, Science, and Technology and the Institut de recherche pour le développement to: - conduct a scoping study of science granting councils in 17 sub-Saharan countries; - organize a regional workshop that will bring together key council representatives to discuss their directions and strategic operations; and, - understand the implications of these trends for IDRC's programming in the region.
The project outputs will include: - a report of the scoping study; - a report of the regional consultation; - a short synthesis building on the scoping study findings and the regional workshop, outlining key recommendations, and identifying follow-up opportunities for IDRC; and, - country policy briefs.
